title: Britain needs a £1.3million-strong volunteer army to fight invasive species in the UK, say MPs
text:
Britain needs a 'citizens' army' of 1.3million volunteers to fight invasive pests, according to a Commons report.

Bugs, animals and weeds from abroad that have set up home in the UK are costing the economy £1.8billion a year, the environmental audit committee warned.

Current Whitehall funding is inadequate to stop pests which could cause devastation to native animals and plants, the economy and human health.

Britain needs a 'citizens' army' of 1.3million volunteers to fight invasive pests, according to a Commons report (stock image)

Around 240 non-native species are expected to become established over the next two decades. A 'step change in awareness' is needed to combat them, the report warned.

Extra vigilance may be needed after Brexit as trade increases with South America and Asia, and more stowaway species arrive in cargo.

Dangers to health include the potential spread of Tiger mosquitoes which could bring tropical diseases previously not seen in the UK, the report warns.

To combat such invaders, the UK should 'replicate the approach taken in New Zealand' by creating a 'biosecurity citizens' army'.

Bugs, animals and weeds from abroad that have set up home in the UK are costing the economy £1.8billion a year, the environmental audit committee warned (stock image)

The report said: 'The Government should significantly expand its approach to public engagement to reach a minimum of two per cent of the population (1.3million) to help identify invasive species and respond to biosecurity outbreaks.'

The UK also needs a 'species border force' by 2020 to improve biosecurity at UK borders.

Committee chairman Mary Creagh said: 'Invasive non-native species are one of the UK's top five threats to the natural environment.'
